commentaries: Montaigne assumes the recipient is familiar with Plutarch's works, implying their philosophical stature.
The author references Plutarch as the original author of a consolatory letter, which he is sending in translation to his wife as a source of comfort.
The author uses Plutarch's account to contrast two historical instances where similar acts of virtue led to different results, highlighting the variability of human judgment.
The author references Plutarch's ideas to argue that human passions, when lacking a proper object, will invent a trivial one.
The author quotes a poet cited within Plutarch's work to support a point about the futility of anger against divine forces.
The author references Plutarch's anecdote about Archidamus mocking Pertander for abandoning his expertise to pursue poetry poorly.
The author references Plutarch's 'Life of Cicero' to note how the Romans used euphemisms for death to soften its harshness.
The author references Plutarch's Life of Paulus Aemilius to illustrate a story about Paulus Emilius and the King of Macedon regarding death and captivity.
The author discusses Plutarch's approach to historical writing, contrasting it with his own method and philosophical stance.
The author references a story about Alexander the Great, which is a known anecdote from Plutarch's biographical works, to illustrate an act of supreme courage and trust.
The author references Plutarch's historical observation that the Romans held scholars in low regard.
The author mentions reading Plutarch as one of the few serious books of solid learning he has engaged with, though he feels he retains little of it.
The author cites Plutarch's 'Apothegms of the Lacedaemonians' to criticize overly long speeches and praise brevity.
The author cites Plutarch's work to recount an anecdote about philosophers' cheerful discourse.
The author aligns with Plutarch's view on Aristotle's educational method for Alexander, emphasizing moral precepts over abstract sciences.
The author cites Plutarch's works as a source of ancient examples of seemingly miraculous speed of news, challenging the reader's skepticism.
The author mentions Plutarch in the context of recounting a story about a brother's indifference, using it to discuss the limitations of fraternal relationships.
The author cites Plutarch's 'Precepts of Marriage' to illustrate Persian customs regarding marital respect and immoderate lust.
The author cites Plutarch's 'Life of Pyrrhus' to show how appearances can contradict common prejudice against barbarians.
The author references Plutarch's complaint about misinterpretations of Cato's death, using it to illustrate how virtue is often misjudged by those with limited sight.
The author cites Plutarch's opinion to argue that excelling in trivial arts indicates a misapplication of one's study.
The author cites Plutarch's account of the Xanthians' mass suicide during Brutus's siege to exemplify extreme devotion to liberty over life.
The author cites Plutarch's observation on the vast inequality in human souls to introduce a discussion on judging individuals by their intrinsic qualities rather than external trappings.
The author cites Plutarch's opinion on the burdens of kingship to support the argument that ruling is a difficult and painful task.
The author mentions Plutarch as an authority whose work has influenced the acceptance of Latin names in French writing.
The author references Plutarch as the source for an anecdote about a man calculating the permutations of the alphabet, presented as an example of vain and frivolous intellectual subtleties.
The author mentions Plutarch as one who inquired into the cause of Alexander the Great's reported fragrant sweat.
The author discusses Plutarch's skepticism about extreme actions attributed to virtue, using his work to explore the limits of moral behavior.
The author mentions reading a passage from Plutarch's works, where Plutarch narrates an anecdote about Rusticus.
The author cites Plutarch as the source of historical information about Julius Caesar's near avoidance of assassination.
The author recounts a story from Plutarch about Archias, the tyrant of Thebes, and his procrastination.
The author defers a discussion on valor, noting that Plutarch has extensively covered the topic already.
The author references Plutarch to provide an example of exceptionally heavy armor used historically.
The author lists Plutarch as a primary source for learning how to marshal opinions and conditions, noting the convenience of his loose, piecemeal discourse.
The author mentions Plutarch alongside Plato as an example of those who fantastically imagined human colonies on the moon, critiquing such ideas as dreams of human vanity.
The author recounts Plutarch's anecdote about a performing dog to demonstrate animal intelligence and trainability.
The author uses Plutarch as a warrant for an anecdote about a pie (magpie).
The author cites another anecdote from Plutarch about a dog's clever behavior.
The author references a saying attributed to Plutarch, using it to support the idea of following animal behavior for health.
The author cites Plutarch as a reliable source for a story about a dog's loyalty, presenting it as a factual account from Plutarch's own time.
The author references Plutarch's first-hand observations and theories regarding the construction of the halcyon's nest.
The author notes that Plutarch shared a similarly dismissive view of metaphysics.
The author questions whether Plutarch's writings, like those of others, contain contradictions upon close examination.
The author references a similar story from Plutarch about a person who preferred the pleasure of inquiry over immediate resolution of doubt.
The author quotes Plutarch to argue that humans presumptuously attempt to discuss divine matters without proper understanding, comparing it to an ignorant person judging music or warfare.
The author cites Plutarch as reporting the existence of mouthless men who nourish themselves by smell.
The author references Plutarch's analogy about the limits of geographical knowledge to illustrate how human inquiry into elevated subjects leads to confusion and absurdity.
The author cites Plutarch's opinion that gods are created from the souls of the saved, noting Plutarch's usual ambiguity but certainty on this point.
The author references Plutarch's mention of sacrificing to the Graces to gain their favor, applying this idea to his own writing process.
The author states that he values Plutarch's writing style more than Seneca's, despite his initial inclination.
The author cites Plutarch's work on divine justice to illustrate a point about revenge and the timing of punishment.
The author praises Plutarch's judgment, specifically referencing his comparison of Lycurgus and Numa to critique parental governance of children.
The author comments on Plutarch's character as revealed through his writings, expressing a desire for more biographical detail.
The author defends Plutarch against Jean Bodin's accusation of relating incredible or fabulous stories, arguing for Plutarch's judgment and credibility.
The author references Plutarch as the source of a story about Agesilaus, using it to discuss the credibility of historical accounts.
The author references Plutarch's judgment that Homer is uniquely ever-fresh and never cloying to readers.
The author cites Plutarch's work 'On the Demon of Socrates' to provide an ancient judgment on Epaminondas's character, specifically his knowledge and reticence.

The author references Plutarch as the source for the detailed lives and characters of notable Greek and Roman figures like Alcibiades and Epaminondas, expressing regret at not having access to these biographies.
The author cites Plutarch as a source for an anecdote about Cato the Censor using hare's milk to maintain his family's health.
The author references Plutarch for an anecdote about the Lacedaemonians' refusal to perform dishonorable acts, using it to argue for the primacy of personal honor over obedience to unjust commands.
The author cites Plutarch's personal grief over his daughter's childhood behaviors as an example of how trivial memories can evoke deep sorrow.
The author quotes a verse translated by Amyot from Plutarch to illustrate the idea that both excess and deficiency in love are errors.
The author refers to Plutarch in describing a quality of bashfulness that has affected his life, using it as a personal example of character traits.
The author cites Plutarch as the source for a saying by Pittacus about marital jealousy, using it to illustrate the universal nature of personal troubles.
The author references Plutarch's observation about language to support his point on how sense illuminates words.
The author expresses deep reliance on Plutarch, praising his universality and richness as a source for embellishing any subject.
The author references Plutarch's 'On Love' for an anecdote about Bion naming adolescent hairs.
The author references Plutarch as an authority who blends art with nature, citing his explanation for seasickness being caused by fear, though no specific book is named.
The author disputes Plutarch's judgment regarding Pompey, indicating skepticism about Plutarch's interpretation of historical figures.
The author references Plutarch's ideas on inconstancy in behavior, applying them to the fickleness of those who enter quarrels without serious consideration.
The author contrasts Plutarch's style with another's, praising it as more manly and persuasive.
Montaigne cites Plutarch as a source for an alternative interpretation of a saying about goodness, noting Plutarch's tendency to present contradictory accounts.
The author cites Plutarch's anecdote about Ctesiphon as an illustration of the foolishness of resisting natural inevitabilities.

Vergil not only transposed the spirit of Greek pastoral into an Italian setting, blending details from the life of his native countryside into the subsequent history of the genre. "Quum de religione agitur, Ti. Coruncanium, P. Scipionem, P. Scaevolam, pontifices maximos, non Zenonem, aut Cleanthem, aut Chrysippum, sequor." ["When matter of religion is in question, I follow the high priests T. Coruncanius, P. Scipio, P. Scaevola, and not Zeno, Cleanthes, or Chrysippus."—Cicero, De Natura Deor., iii. 2.]
would I extract consolation for myself or my friend, I borrow it from Cicero
"Ut fuerit melius non didicisse." ["So that it were better not to have learned." —Cicero, Tusc. Quaes., ii. 4.]

"Si quid Socrates ant Aristippus contra morem et consuetudinem fecerunt, idem sibi ne arbitretur licere: magnis enim illi et divinis bonis hanc licentiam assequebantur." ["If Socrates and Aristippus have committed any act against manners and custom, let him not think that he is allowed to do the same; for it was by great and divine benefits that they obtained this privilege."—Cicero, De Offic., i. 41.]

"Neque, ut omnia, qux praescripta et imperata sint, defendat, necessitate ulla cogitur." ["Neither is their any necessity upon him, that he should defend all things that are prescribed and enjoined him." —Cicero, Acad., ii. 3.]
One asking Socrates of what country he was, he did not make answer, of Athens, but of the world;—[Cicero, Tusc. Quaes., v. 37; Plutarch, On Exile, c. 4.]

Cicero said, that though he should live two men’s ages, he should never find leisure to study the lyric poets;

"Hanc amplissimam omnium artium bene vivendi disciplinam, vita magis quam literis, persequuti sunt." [“They have proceeded to this discipline of living well, which of all arts is the greatest, by their lives, rather than by their reading.”—Cicero, Tusc. Quaes., iv. 3.]

"Qui disciplinam suam non ostentationem scientiae, sed legem vitae putet: quique obtemperet ipse sibi, et decretis pareat." [“Who considers his own discipline, not as a vain ostentation of science, but as a law and rule of life; and who obeys his own decrees, and the laws he has prescribed for himself.” —Cicero, Tusc. Quaes., ii. 4.]
"Ipsae res verbs rapiunt." ["The things themselves force the words to express them." —Cicero, De Finib., iii. 5.]
If these ridiculous subtleties, "Contorta et aculeata sophismata," as Cicero calls them, are designed to possess him with an untruth, they are dangerous;

"Ut necesse est, lancem in Libra, ponderibus impositis, deprimi, sic animum perspicuis cedere." ["As the scale of the balance must give way to the weight that presses it down, so the mind yields to demonstration." —Cicero, Acad., ii. 12.]

"Consuetudine oculorum assuescunt animi, neque admirantur, neque requirunt rationes earum rerum, quas semper vident." ["Things grow familiar to men's minds by being often seen; so that they neither admire nor are they inquisitive about things they daily see."—Cicero, De Natura Deor., lib. ii. 38.]
"Qui, ut rationem nullam afferrent, ipsa auctoritate me frangerent." ["Who, though they should adduce no reason, would convince me with their authority alone."—Cicero, Tusc. Quaes, i. 21.]
“Amorem conatum esse amicitiae faciendae ex pulchritudinis specie.” [“Love is a desire of contracting friendship arising from the beauty of the object.”—Cicero, Tusc. Quaes., vi. 34.]

“Omnino amicitiae, corroboratis jam confirmatisque, et ingeniis, et aetatibus, judicandae sunt.” [“Those are only to be reputed friendships that are fortified and confirmed by judgement and the length of time.” —Cicero, De Amicit., c. 20.]
When Laelius,—[Cicero, De Amicit., c. II. ]—in the presence of the Roman consuls...

“O what a charming boy is that!” said he. “That might be very well,” answered Pericles, “for any other than a praetor, who ought not only to have his hands, but his eyes, too, chaste.”—[Cicero, De Offic., i. 40.]
"Sunt qui nihil suadent, quam quod se imitari posse confidunt." ["There are who persuade nothing but what they believe they can imitate themselves."—Cicero, De Orator., c. 7.]
"Quam vereri deberent, etiam si percipere non possent." ["Which they ought to reverence, though they cannot comprehend." —Cicero, Tusc. Quas., v. 2.]
like Cicero, who says that he would employ his solitude and retirement from public affairs to acquire by his writings an immortal life.
"Obversentur species honestae animo;" ["Let honest things be ever present to the mind" —Cicero, Tusc. Quaes., ii. 22.]
There are to be gathered out of the writings of Cicero and the younger Pliny (but little, in my opinion, resembling his uncle in his humours) infinite testimonies of a beyond measure ambitious nature

"Quoties non modo ductores nostri, sed universi etiam exercitus, ad non dubiam mortem concurrerunt?" ["How often have not only our leaders, but whole armies, run to a certain and manifest death."—Cicero, Tusc. Quaes., i. 37.]
"Ex quo intelligitur, non in natura, sed in opinione, esse aegritudinem." ["By which one may understand that grief is not in nature, but in opinion."—Cicero, Tusc. Quaes., iii. 28.]
"Non esse cupidum, pecunia est; non esse emacem, vertigal est." ["Not to be covetous, is money; not to be acquisitive, is revenue." —Cicero, Paradox., vi. 3.]
"Divinarum fructus est in copia; copiam declarat satietas." ["The fruit of riches is in abundance; satiety declares abundance." —Idem, ibid., vi. 2.]

"It is an effeminate and flimsy opinion, nor more so in pain than in pleasure, in which, while we are at our ease, we cannot bear without a cry the sting of a bee. The whole business is to commend thyself."—Cicero, Tusc. Quaes., ii. 22.
for, as Cicero says, even those who most controvert it, would yet that the books they write about it should visit the light under their own names, and seek to derive glory from seeming to despise it.

"Tales sunt hominum mentes, quali pater ipse Juppiter auctificas lustravit lumine terras." ["Such are the minds of men, that they change as the light with which father Jupiter himself has illumined the increasing earth." —Cicero, Frag. Poet, lib. x.]
Many of the Greeks, says Cicero,—[Cicero, Tusc. Quaes., ii. 27. ]— cannot endure the sight of an enemy, and yet are courageous in sickness; the Cimbrians and Celtiberians quite contrary;
"Nihil enim potest esse aequabile, quod non a certa ratione proficiscatur." ["Nothing can be regular that does not proceed from a fixed ground of reason."—Idem, ibid., c. 26.]
"Cui vivendi via considerata atque provisa est," ["If the way of his life is thoroughly considered and traced out." —Cicero, Paradox, v. 1.]

“Occupavi te, Fortuna, atque cepi: omnesque aditus tuos interclusi ut ad me aspirare non posses;” [“Fortune, I have got the better of thee, and have made all the avenues so sure thou canst not come at me.” —Cicero, Tusc. Quaes., v. 9.]
for as to arms, says Cicero, they were so accustomed to have them always on, that they were no more trouble to them than their own limbs: “Arma enim membra militis esse dicunt.”
As to Cicero, his works that are most useful to my design are they that treat of manners and rules of our life.
wherein he not only excels all other historians, as Cicero confesses, but, peradventure, even Cicero himself;
"Sic abiit a vita, ut causam moriendi nactum se esse gauderet." ["He quitted life rejoicing that a reason for dying had arisen." —Cicero, Tusc. Quaes., i. 30.]

"Catoni, quum incredibilem natura tribuisset gravitatem, eamque ipse perpetue constantia roboravisset, semperque in proposito consilio permansisset, moriendum potius, quam tyranni vultus aspiciendus, erat." ["Cato, whom nature had given incredible dignity, which he had fortified by perpetual constancy, ever remaining of his predetermined opinion, preferred to die rather than to look on the countenance of a tyrant."—Cicero, De Ofc., i. 31.]
"Bellux a barbaris propter beneficium consecratae." ["Beasts, out of opinion of some benefit received by them, were consecrated by barbarians"—Cicero, De Natura Deor., i. 36.]
And what qualities of our bodily constitution, in Plato and Cicero, may not indifferently serve a thousand sorts of beasts?

"There is nothing," says Cicero, "so charming as the employment of letters; of letters, I say, by means whereof the infinity of things, the immense grandeur of nature, the heavens even in this world, the earth, and the seas are discovered to us; 'tis they that have taught us religion, moderation, and the grandeur of courage, and that have rescued our souls from darkness, to make her see all things, high, low, first, last, and middling; 'tis they that furnish us wherewith to live happily and well, and conduct us to pass over our lives without displeasure, and without offence."

Atque illum quidem parentem hujus universitaiis invenire, difficile; et, quum jam inveneris, indicare in vulgtis, nefas: "to find out the parent of the world is very difficult; and when found out, to reveal him to the vulgar is sin," says Cicero.

And of Cicero himself, who stood indebted to his learning for all he was worth, Valerius says, "That he began to disrelish letters in his old age; and when at his studies, it was with great independency upon any one party; following what he thought probable, now in one sect, and then in another, evermore wavering under the doubts of the academy."

Hear Cicero’s protestation, who expounds to us another’s fancy by his own: Qui requirunt quid de quque re ipsi sentiamus, curiosius id faciunt quam necesse est,... Hoc in philosophi ratio, contra omnia disserendi, nuttamque rem aperte judicandi, profecta a Socrate, repetita ab Arcesila, conjirmata a Gameade, usqu ad nostram viget cetatem..........Hi sumus, qui omnibus veris falsa quodam adjuncta esse dicamus, tanta similitudine, ut in iis nulla insit certe judicandi et assentiendi nota.

after all this enumeration of opinions, Harum sententiarum quo vera sit, Deus aliquis viderit: "Of these opinions which is the true, let some god determine," says Cicero.

Cicero says, that Chrysippus having attempted to extenuate the force and virtue of the senses, presented to himself arguments and so vehement oppositions to the contrary that he could not satisfy himself therein; whereupon Cameades, who maintained the contrary side, boasted that he would make use of the very words and arguments of Chrysippus to controvert and confute him, and therefore thus cried out against him: “O miserable! thy force has destroyed thee.”
"Non emolumento aliquo, sed ipsius honestatis decore." ["Not for any profit, but for the honour of honesty itself." —Cicero, De Finib., i. 10.]

"An quidquam stultius, quam, quos singulos contemnas, eos aliquid putare esse universes?" ["Can anything be more foolish than to think that those you despise singly, can be anything else in general." —Cicero, Tusc. Quaes., v. 36.]

"Ego hoc judico, si quando turpe non sit, tamen non esse non turpe, quum id a multitudine laudatur." ["I am of opinion, that though a thing be not foul in itself, yet it cannot but become so when commended by the multitude." —Cicero, De Finib., ii. 15.]

"Ut enim consuetudo loquitur, id solum dicitur honestum, quod est populari fama gloriosum;" ["As custom puts it, that only is called honest which is glorious by the public voice."—Cicero, De Finibus, ii. 15.]
"Nil est tam populare, quam bonitas." ["Nothing is so popular as an agreeable manner (goodness)." —Cicero, Pro Ligar., c. 12.]

"Quo quis versutior et callidior est, hoc invisior et suspectior, detracto opinione probitatis:" ["By how much any one is more subtle and cunning, by so much is he hated and suspected, the opinion of his integrity being withdrawn." —Cicero, De Off., ii. 9.]

"Memoria certe non modo Philosophiam sed omnis vitae usum, omnesque artes, una maxime continet." ["It is certain that memory contains not only philosophy, but all the arts and all that appertain to the use of life." —Cicero, Acad., ii. 7.]
"Ipsa consuetudo assentiendi periculosa esse videtur, et lubrica;" ["The very custom of assenting seems to be dangerous and slippery."—Cicero, Acad., ii. 21.]

"Omnino si quidquam est decorum, nihil est profecto magis, quam aequabilitas universae vitae, tum singularum actionum, quam conservare non possis, si, aliorum naturam imitans, omittas tuam." ["If anything be entirely decorous, nothing certainly can be more so than an equability alike in the whole life and in every particular action; which thou canst not possibly observe if, imitating other men's natures, thou layest aside thy own."—Cicero, De Of., i. 31.]
Hear Cicero speak of the love of liberty: hear Brutus speak of it, the mere written words of this man sound as if he would purchase it at the price of his life.

as what Cicero has also testified before him, as having, as he says, been upon the spot: that even to their times there were children found who, in the trial of patience they were put to before the altar of Diana, suffered themselves to be there whipped...
"Utatur motu animi, qui uti ratione non potest." ["He may employ his passion, who can make no use of his reason." —Cicero, Tusc. Quaes., iv. 25.]
"Id maxime quemque decet, quod est cujusque suum maxime." ["That best becomes every man which belongs most to him;" —Cicero, De Offic., i. 31.]

"Veri juris germanaeque justitiae solidam et expressam effigiem nullam tenemus; umbra et imaginibus utimur;" ["We retain no solid and express portraiture of true right and germane justice; we have only the shadow and image of it." —Cicero, De Offic., iii. 17.]

"Tuo tibi judicio est utendum.... Virtutis et vitiorum grave ipsius conscientiae pondus est: qua sublata, jacent omnia." ["Thou must employ thy own judgment upon thyself; great is the weight of thy own conscience in the discovery of virtues and vices: which taken away, all things are lost." —Cicero, De Nat. Dei, iii. 35; Tusc. Quaes., i. 25.]
"Quibus vivere est cogitare;" ["To whom to live is to think."—Cicero, Tusc. Quaes., v. 28.]
"Nam nos quoque oculos eruditos habemus." ["For we also have eyes that are versed in the matter." —Cicero, Paradox, v. 2.]
nor making a bundle of all these together, to make use of upon occasion, according to Cicero

"Sibi arma, sibi equos, sibi hastas, sibi clavam, sibi pilam, sibi natationes, et cursus habeant: nobis senibus, ex lusionibus multis, talos relinquant et tesseras;" ["Let them reserve to themselves arms, horses, spears, clubs, tennis, swimming, and races; and of all the sports leave to us old men cards and dice."—Cicero, De Senec., c. 16.]
"In fragili corpore odiosa omnis offensio est;" ["In a fragile body every shock is obnoxious." —Cicero, De Senec., c. 18.]
I should doubtless say, as Cicero did, could I speak as well as he.
"Nec ad melius vivendum, nec ad commodius disserendum." ["It neither makes a man live better nor talk better." —Cicero, De Fin., i. 19.]

"Videndum est, non modo quid quisque loquatur, sed etiam quid quisque sentiat, atque etiam qua de causa quisque sentiat." ["A man is not only to examine what every one says, but also what every one thinks, and from what reason every one thinks." —Cicero, De Offic:, i. 41.]

"Fructus enim ingenii et virtutis, omnisque praestantiae, tum maximus capitur, quum in proximum quemque confertur:" ["For the greatest enjoyment of evil and virtue, and of all excellence, is experienced when they are conferred on some one nearest."—Cicero, De Amicil., c.]
"Servitus obedientia est fracti animi et abjecti, arbitrio carentis suo." ["Servitude is the obedience of a subdued and abject mind, wanting its own free will."—Cicero, Paradox, V. 1.]
"Hoc ipsum ita justum est, quod recte fit, si est voluntarium." ["This itself is so far just, that it is rightly done, if it is voluntary."—Cicero, De Offic., i. 9.]

"Est prudentis sustinere, ut currum, sic impetum benevolentia;" ["'Tis the part of a wise man to keep a curbing hand upon the impetus of friendship, as upon that of his horse." —Cicero, De Amicit., c. 17.]
"Rerum natura nullam nobis dedit cognitionem finium." ["Nature has green to us no knowledge of the end of things." —Cicero, Acad., ii. 29.]

“Si contigerit ea vita sapienti, ut ommum rerum afliuentibus copiis, quamvis omnia, quae cognitione digna sunt, summo otio secum ipse consideret et contempletur, tamen, si solitudo tanta sit, ut hominem videre non possit, excedat a vita.” [“If such a condition of life should happen to a wise man, that in the greatest plenty of all conveniences he might, at the most undisturbed leisure, consider and contemplate all things worth the knowing, yet if his solitude be such that he must not see a man, let him depart from life.”—Cicero, De Offic., i. 43.]

“Tanta vis admonitionis inest in locis....Et id quidem in hac urbe infinitum; quacumque enim ingredimur, in aliquam historiam vestigium ponimus.” [“So great a power of reminiscence resides in places; and that truly in this city infinite, for which way soever we go, we find the traces of some story.”—Cicero, De Fin., v. I, 2.]

"Etenim ipsae se impellunt, ubi semel a ratione discessum est; ipsaque sibi imbecillitas indulget, in altumque provehitur imprudens, nec reperit locum consistendi." ["For they throw themselves headlong when once they lose their reason; and infirmity so far indulges itself, and from want of prudence is carried out into deep water, nor finds a place to shelter it."—Cicero, Tusc. Quaes., iv. 18.]

"Convenit a litibus, quantum licet, et nescio an paulo plus etiam quam licet, abhorrentem esse: est enim non modo liberale, paululum nonnunquam de suo jure decedere, sed interdum etiam fructuosum." ["A man should abhor lawsuits as much as he may, and I know not whether not something more; for 'tis not only liberal, but sometimes also advantageous, too, a little to recede from one's right."—Cicero, De Offic., ii. 18.]
"Quae est ista laus quae: possit e macello peti?" ["What praise is that which is to be got in the market-place (meat market)?" Cicero, De Fin., ii. 15.]

"Mihi quidem laudabiliora videntur omnia, quae sine venditatione, et sine populo teste fiunt," ["All things truly seem more laudable to me that are performed without ostentation, and without the testimony of the people." —Cicero, Tusc. Quaes., ii. 26.]

"Ita finitima sunt falsa veris, ut in praecipitem locum non debeat se sapiens committere." ["False things are so near the true, that a wise man should not trust himself in a precipitous place"—Cicero, Acad., ii. 21.]
"Quasi vero quidquam sit tam valde, quam nil sapere, vulgare." ["As if anything were so common as ignorance." —Cicero, De Divin., ii.]

Iris is the daughter of Thaumas; ["That is, of Admiration. She (Iris, the rainbow) is beautiful, and for that reason, because she has a face to be admired, she is said to have been the daughter of Thamus." —Cicero, De Nat. Deor., iii. 20.]
"Videantur sane, non affirmentur modo;" ["They may indeed appear to be; let them not be affirmed (Let them state the probabilities, but not affirm.)" —Cicero, Acad., n. 27.]
"Nec me pudet, ut istos fateri nescire, quod nesciam;" ["Neither am I ashamed, as they are, to confess my ignorance of what I do not know."—Cicero, Tusc. Quaes., i. 25.]
"Perspicuitas enim argumentatione elevatur;" ["For perspicuity is lessened by argument." ("The clearness of a cause is clouded by argumentation.") —Cicero, De Nat. Deor., iii. 4.]
"Tota philosophorum vita commentatio mortis est;" ["The whole life of philosophers is the meditation of death." —Cicero, Tusc. Quaes., ii. 30.]

"Ipsi animi magni refert, quali in corpore locati sint: multo enim a corpore existunt, qux acuant mentem: multa qua obtundant;" ["It is of great consequence in what bodies minds are placed, for many things spring from the body that may sharpen the mind, and many that may blunt it."—Cicero, Tusc. Quaes., i. 33.]

"Nihil est turpius, quam cognitioni et perceptions assertionem approbationemque praecurrere." ["Nothing is worse than that assertion and decision should precede knowledge and perception."—Cicero, Acad., i. 13.]
"Sola sapientia in se tota conversa est." ["Wisdom only is wholly within itself"—Cicero, De Fin., iii. 7.]
By suchlike arguments, weak and strong, as Cicero with the disease of his old age, I try to rock asleep and amuse my imagination, and to dress its wounds.
"Omnia, quae secundum naturam fiunt, sunt habenda in bonis." ["All things that are done according to nature are to be accounted good."—Cicero, De Senect., c. 19.]
"Vitam adolescentibus vis aufert, senibus maturitas." ["Young men are taken away by violence, old men by maturity." —Cicero, ubi sup.]

"Eodem enim vitio est effusio animi in laetitia quo in dolore contractio," ["For from the same imperfection arises the expansion of the mind in pleasure and its contraction in sorrow." —Cicero, Tusc. Quaes., iv. 31.]
"Omnia quae secundum naturam sunt, aestimatione digna sunt." ["All things that are according to nature are worthy of esteem." —Cicero, De Fin., iii. 6.]
"Intrandum est in rerum naturam, et penitus, quid ea postulet, pervidendum." ["A man must search into the nature of things, and fully examine what she requires."—Cicero, De Fin., V. 16.]
commentaries: The author references Q. Cicero's less direct expression on friendship and obligation, comparing it to the statements of Tacitus and Seneca.
The author references Cicero as a source reporting a saying from a Greek poet, using it to illustrate a philosophical attitude towards death.
The author quotes Cicero's 'Tusculanae Disputationes' to support the argument that burial customs are for the living, not the dead.
The author references Cicero's 'Tusculan Disputations' as the source for a saying attributed to the philosopher Bion.
The author cites Cicero's 'De Officiis' for a sentiment advocating the resolution of conflict through valor.
The author quotes a Latin maxim attributed to Cicero, using it to introduce a discussion on military treachery.
The author cites Cicero referencing the idea of keeping a record of wrongs, connecting it to a subsequent anecdote about Darius.
The author cites Cicero's idea that philosophy is a preparation for death, using it to introduce the essay's central theme.
The author uses Cicero's metaphor of the stone of Tantalus to describe how the constant threat of death looms over human life.
The author quotes Cicero to criticize the reliance on custom-bound minds for testimonies of truth, using it to argue that custom heavily prejudices human judgment and belief.
The author quotes Cicero to emphasize the persuasive power of ancient traditions and monuments.
The author cites Cicero to argue for following traditional religious authorities over philosophers like Zeno, Cleanthes, or Chrysippus.
The author criticizes the habit of borrowing consolation from Cicero instead of finding it within oneself.
The author cites Cicero to support the idea that learning can be dangerous if not properly applied.
The author cites Cicero to argue that only men of great souls, like Socrates and Aristippus, can legitimately defy custom.
The author quotes Cicero to emphasize that one is not compelled to defend all prescribed opinions, highlighting intellectual freedom.
The author references Cicero (and Plutarch) to illustrate Socrates' cosmopolitan worldview, contrasting it with narrower perspectives.
The author cites Cicero's 'Tusculanae Disputationes' as the intermediary source for Pythagoras's saying.
The author quotes Cicero on the lack of time for studying lyric poets, using it to emphasize the limited time available for a child's education.
The author references Cicero to argue that the art of living well is learned through life experience rather than books.
The author quotes Cicero to emphasize that true discipline should be a practical rule for life, not mere theoretical knowledge.
The author quotes Cicero's 'De Finibus' to further illustrate the idea that substance dictates expression.
The author references Cicero's term for sophistical arguments to critique deceptive rhetoric.
The author cites Cicero's 'Academica' to illustrate the idea that the mind yields to clear demonstration, using it as an analogy for belief.
The author quotes Cicero's 'De Natura Deorum' to emphasize how habit dulls curiosity and wonder.
The author quotes Cicero's 'Tusculanae Disputationes' to emphasize the power of authority in persuasion, particularly in the context of religious belief.
The author cites Cicero's definition of love from the Tusculan Disputations to contrast with his own view of friendship.
The author quotes Cicero's De Amicitia to support his own, more stringent definition of true friendship.
The author references the story of Laelius and Blosius from Cicero's De Amicitia as an example of absolute trust within perfect friendship.
The author references Cicero's 'De Officiis' for an anecdote about Pericles emphasizing the chastity required of public officials.
The author quotes Cicero to support the idea that people often only advocate for what they think they can emulate themselves.
The author quotes Cicero to argue that virtue should be revered even if it is not fully understood.
The author references Cicero's aim to achieve immortality through writing during retirement.
The author quotes Cicero's Tusculan Disputations to advise keeping virtuous examples in mind.
The author references the writings of Cicero as evidence of an ambitious nature, using them for critical analysis of character.
The author references Cicero to support the idea that people throughout history have willingly embraced certain death for their causes or beliefs.
The author quotes Cicero's 'Tusculanae Disputationes' to support the argument that grief is a matter of opinion rather than nature.
The author quotes Cicero to argue that freedom from greed is equivalent to possessing wealth, aligning with his reformed attitude toward money.
The author references Cicero again to convey that true wealth lies in having enough and feeling satisfied, rather than in accumulation.
The author cites Cicero's Tusculan Disputations to critique human frailty in enduring pain and to emphasize self-mastery.
The author references Cicero to illustrate the universal human desire for glory, noting that even philosophers who argue against it still seek personal recognition for their writings.
The author quotes Cicero to illustrate the fluctuating nature of human minds.
The author cites Cicero as an authority for an observation about the inconsistent nature of courage among different peoples.
The author quotes Cicero's 'Tusculan Disputations' to argue that true consistency must be rooted in reason.
The author quotes Cicero's 'Paradoxa Stoicorum' to describe the ideal of a life guided by a premeditated plan.
The author quotes Cicero's account of Metrodorus's defiance of fortune, illustrating Stoic boasts of invulnerability.
The author cites Cicero to emphasize how Roman soldiers were so habituated to wearing armor that it became second nature.
The author acknowledges Cicero's works on manners and life as useful, but criticizes his writing style as negligent, uninviting, and overly preoccupied with preliminaries.
The author references Cicero's acknowledgment of Caesar's excellence in language, suggesting Caesar may surpass even Cicero.
The author quotes Cicero's 'Tusculanae Disputationes' to support the idea that Cato the Younger found joy in having a reason to die.
The author quotes Cicero's 'De Officiis' to illustrate Cato the Younger's unwavering principle and dignity in choosing death over submission to tyranny.

Testo greco a fronte
Una delle tragedie greche piu famose e rappresentate. Il dramma di una amore assoluto che si trasforma, per il tradimento di Giasone, in feroce odio e desiderio di vendetta. Una vendetta che coinvolgera anche i figli che Medea ha avuto da Giasone.

contexts: But, to pursue the business of this essay, I have always thought that, in poesy, Virgil, Lucretius, Catullus, and Horace by many degrees excel the rest; and signally, Virgil in his Georgics, which I look upon as the most accomplished piece in poetry; and in comparison of which a man may easily discern that there are some places in his AEneids, to which the author would have given a little more of the file, had he had leisure: and the fifth book of his AEneids seems to me the most perfect.
“Et via vix tandem voci laxata dolore est.” [“And at length and with difficulty is a passage opened by grief for utterance.”—AEneid, xi. 151.]

“Atque idem fugientem baud est dignatus Oroden Sternere, nec jacta caecum dare cuspide vulnus Obvius, adversoque occurrit, seque viro vir Contulit, haud furto melior, sed fortibus armis.” [“He deigned not to throw down Orodes as he fled, or with the darted spear to give him a wound unseen; but overtaking him, he confronted him face to face, and encountered man to man: superior, not in stratagem, but in valiant arms.”—AEneid, x. 732.]

“Sicut aqua tremulum labris ubi lumen ahenis, Sole repercussum, aut radiantis imagine lunae, Omnia pervolitat late loca; jamque sub auras Erigitur, summique ferit laquearia tecti.” [“As when in brazen vats of water the trembling beams of light, reflected from the sun, or from the image of the radiant moon, swiftly float over every place around, and now are darted up on high, and strike the ceilings of the upmost roof.”— AEneid, viii. 22.]
"Mens immota manet; lachrymae volvuntur inanes." ["Though tears flow, the mind remains unmoved." —Virgil, AEneid, iv. 449]
"Obstupui, steteruntque comae et vox faucibus haesit." ["I was amazed, my hair stood on end, and my voice stuck in my throat." Virgil, AEneid, ii. 774.]
"Quern semper acerbum, Semper honoratum (sic, di, voluistis) habebo," ["A day for me ever sad, for ever sacred, so have you willed ye gods."—AEneid, v. 49.]
for “Non levia aut ludicra petuntur Praemia;” [“They aim at no slight or jocular rewards.”—AEneid, xii. 764.]
“Id cinerem et manes credis curare sepultos?” [“Do you believe the dead regard such things?”—AEneid, iv. 34.]
“Inde thoro pater AEneas sic orsus ab alto.” [“Thus Father AEneas, from his high bed of state, spoke.” —AEneid, ii. 2.]
“Sic fatur lacrymans, classique immittit habenas.” [“Thus he speaks, weeping, and then sets sail with his fleet.” —Aeneid, vi. i.]

"Ad nos vix tenuis famx perlabitur aura." ["An obscure rumour scarce is hither come."—AEneid, vii. 646.]

"Magno veluti cum flamma sonore Virgea suggeritur costis undantis ahem, Exsultantque aatu latices, furit intus aquae vis. Fumidus atque alte spumis exuberat amnis, Nec jam se capit unda; volat vapor ater ad auras;" ["When with loud crackling noise, a fire of sticks is applied to the boiling caldron’s side, by the heat in frisky bells the liquor dances; within the water rages, and high the smoky fluid in foam overflows. Nor can the wave now contain itself; the black steam flies all abroad."—AEneid, vii. 462.]

"Ac veluti montis saxum de, vertice praeceps Cum ruit avulsum vento, seu turbidus imber Proluit, aut annis solvit sublapsa vetustas, Fertur in abruptum magno mons improbus actu, Exultatque solo, silvas, armenta, virosque, Involvens secum." ["And as a stone torn from the mountain's top by the wind or rain torrents, or loosened by age, falls massive with mighty force, bounds here and there, in its course sweeps from the earth with it woods, herds, and men."—AEneid, xii. 684.]
and that one touch of the Iliad has supplied him with body and matter out of which to compose his great and divine AEneid.

"Spero equidem mediis, si quid pia numina possunt, Supplicia hausurum scopulis, et nomine Dido Saepe vocaturum . . . Audiam; et haec Manes veniet mihi fama sub imos." Ea verba loquutus, Optatos dedit amplexus; placidumque petivit Conjugis infusus gremio per membra soporem.” [“The goddess spoke, and throwing round him her snowy arms in soft embraces, caresses him hesitating. Suddenly he caught the wonted flame, and the well-known warmth pierced his marrow, and ran thrilling through his shaken bones: just as when at times, with thunder, a stream of fire in lightning flashes shoots across the skies. Having spoken these words, he gave her the wished embrace, and in the bosom of his spouse sought placid sleep.” —AEneid, viii. 387 and 392.]

"Indum sanguineo veluti violaverit ostro Si quis ebur, vel mista rubent ubi lilia multa Alba rosa." ["As Indian ivory streaked with crimson, or white lilies mixed with the damask rose."—AEneid, xii. 67.]
"Tum vero in curas animum diducimus omnes;" ["Indeed we lead the mind into all sorts of cares." —AEneid, v. 720.]

"Quisque suos patimur manes." ["We each of us suffer our own particular demon."—AEneid, vi. 743.]

"Velut rupes, vastum quae prodit in aequor, Obvia ventorum furiis, expostaque ponto, Vim cunctam atque minas perfert coelique marisque; Ipsa immota manens." to which Plato, in his Republic, gives, methinks, too much authority.

and the first article that Plato requires in the governor of his Republic.
Plato indifferently invites both the one and the other to the society of all studies, exercises, and vocations, both military and civil, in his Commonwealth;
Therefore it is that Plato in his Republic prohibits this exercise to fools and ill-bred people.

St. Augustin, Origeti, and Hippocrates have published the errors of their opinions; I, moreover, of my manners.

The disciples of Hegesias, who starved themselves to death, animated thereunto by his fine lectures, and in such numbers that King Ptolemy ordered he should be forbidden to entertain his followers with such homicidal doctrines, did not consider death in itself, neither did they judge of it; it was not there they fixed their thoughts; they ran towards and aimed at a new being.
commentaries: The author references the doctrine of Hegesias to support the idea that a wise man should act only for himself, as he alone is worthy.

raw.title: De Officiis
raw.author: Cicero
contexts: "Meminerint Deum se habere testem, id est (ut ego arbitror) mentem suam." ["Let them consider they have God to witness, that is (as I interpret it), their own consciences."—Cicero, De Offic., iii. 10.]
"Quasi non sit honestum, quod nobilitatum non sit;" ["As though it were not a virtue, unless celebrated" —Cicero De Offic. iii. 10.]

"Vera et sapiens animi magnitudo, honestum illud, quod maxime naturam sequitur, in factis positum, non in gloria, judicat." ["The true and wise magnanimity judges that the bravery which most follows nature more consists in act than glory." —Cicero, De Offic. i. 19.]
"Quasi vero forti viro vis possit adhiberi." ["As though a man of true courage could be compelled." —Cicero, De Offic., iii. 30.]

"Non enim patria praestat omnibus officiis.... et ipsi conducit pios habere cives in parentes." ["The duty to one’s country does not supersede all other duties. The country itself requires that its citizens should act piously toward their parents."—Cicero, De Offic., iii. 23.]

["By how much more you use it to many, by so much less will you be in a capacity to use it to many more. And what greater folly can there be than to order it so that what you would willingly do, you cannot do longer."—Cicero, De Offic., ii. 15.]
["The transferring of money from the right owners to strangers ought not to have the title of liberality." —Cicero, De Offic., i. 14.]
"Non tam commutandarum quam evertendarum rerum cupidi." ["Not so desirous of changing as of overthrowing things." —Cicero, De Offic., ii. i.]

"Sic est faciendum, ut contra naturam universam nihil contendamus; ea tamen conservata propriam sequamur." ["We must so order it as by no means to contend against universal nature; but yet, that rule being observed, to follow our own." —Cicero, De Offcc., i. 31.]
"Neque submissam et abjectam, neque se efferentem;" ["Neither subject and abject, nor obtrusive." —Cicero, De Offic., i. 34]
commentaries: The author quotes Cicero to argue that one's own conscience, not public witness, should be the judge of virtuous action.

The author references Cicero's De Officiis to argue that the lavish public spectacles of Roman emperors, funded from state resources, should not be mistaken for true personal liberality.
The author cites Cicero's De Officiis to criticize those who seek to overthrow rather than reform governments.
The author references Cicero's 'De Officiis' to argue for following one's own nature while not opposing universal nature.
The author quotes Cicero's De Officiis to commend a life of moderation that is neither servile nor ostentatious.

goodreads_match.title: On Old Age
goodreads_match.description:
The relevance of Cicero's On Old Age transcends time and culture as it examines with superlative clarity the challenging problem of aging.
Cicero brilliantly addresses the aspects of old age and its sociological problems in a manner that is as relevant today as it was two thousand years ago. With Latin text, notes, and vocabulary, this is a valuable text that intermediate students will find instructive and insightful.

raw.title: Georgics
raw.author: Virgil
contexts: But, to pursue the business of this essay, I have always thought that, in poesy, Virgil, Lucretius, Catullus, and Horace by many degrees excel the rest; and signally, Virgil in his Georgics, which I look upon as the most accomplished piece in poetry; and in comparison of which a man may easily discern that there are some places in his AEneids, to which the author would have given a little more of the file, had he had leisure: and the fifth book of his AEneids seems to me the most perfect.
“Extrema per illos Justitia excedens terris vestigia fecit.” [“Justice, when she left the earth, took her last steps among them.”—Virgil, Georg., ii. 473.]
“Quo rapiat sitiens Venerem, interiusque recondat.” [“But let him thirstily snatch the joys of love and enclose them in his bosom.”—Virg., Georg., iii. 137.]

“Omne adeo genus in terris, hominumque, ferarumque, Et genus aequoreum, pecudes, pictaeque volucres, In furias ignemque ruunt.” [“So that all living things, men and animals, wild or tame, and fish and gaudy fowl, rush to this flame of love.” —Virgil, Georg., iii. 244.]
"Quippe ubi fas versum atque nefas," ["Where wrong and right have changed places." —Virgil, Georg., i. 504.]

"Felix, qui potuit rerum cognoscere causas, Atque metus omnes et inexorabile fatum Subjecit pedibus, strepitumque Acherontis avari! Fortunatus et ille, Deos qui novit agrestes, Panaque, Sylvanumque senem, Nymphasque sorores!" ["Happy is he who could discover the causes of things, and place under his feet all fears and inexorable fate, and the sound of rapacious Acheron: he is blest who knows the country gods, and Pan, and old Sylvanus, and the sister nymphs."—Virgil, Georg., ii. 490.]
"Videas desertaque regna Pastorum, et longe saltus lateque vacantes." ["You would see shepherds' haunts deserted, and far and wide empty pastures."—Virgil, Georg., iii. 476.]
"Curis acuens mortalia corda!" ["Probing mortal hearts with cares."—Virgil, Georg., i. 23.]
commentaries: The author praises Virgil, especially the Georgics as the most accomplished poetic work, and comments on the Aeneid.

The author cites Virgil's 'Georgics' to emphasize that rare virtue is often found among people of mean condition, using the quote to illustrate the exceptional character of the woman from the lower class.

goodreads_match.title: Odyssey
goodreads_match.description: The Odyssey is, quite simply, the story of Odysseus, who wants to go home. But Poseidon, god of oceans, doesn't want him to make it back across the wine-dark sea to his wife, Penelope, son, Telemachus, and their high-roofed home at Ithaca. The story is told in easy-going, beautiful poetry; the characters speak naturally, the action happens briskly. Even the gods come across as real people, despite the divine powers they exercise constantly.

raw.author: Nicocles
contexts: And, besides, they have a very advantageous way of making use of all sorts of events: for what fortune, nature, or any other cause (of which the number is infinite), products of good and healthful in us, it is the privilege of physic to attribute to itself; all the happy successes that happen to the patient, must be thence derived; the accidents that have cured me, and a thousand others, who do not employ physicians, physicians usurp to themselves: and as to ill accidents, they either absolutely disown them, in laying the fault upon the patient, by such frivolous reasons as they are never at a loss for; as “he lay with his arms out of bed,” or “he was disturbed with the rattling of a coach:” “Rhedarum transitus arcto Vicorum inflexu:” [“The passage of the wheels in the narrow turning of the street”—Juvenal, iii. 236.] or “somebody had set open the casement,” or “he had lain upon his left side,” or “he had some disagreeable fancies in his head”: in sum, a word, a dream, or a look, seems to them excuse sufficient wherewith to palliate their own errors: or, if they so please, they even make use of our growing worse, and do their business in this way which can never fail them: which is by buzzing us in the ear, when the disease is more inflamed by their medicaments, that it had been much worse but for those remedies; he, whom from an ordinary cold they have thrown into a double tertian-ague, had but for them been in a continued fever. They do not much care what mischief they do, since it turns to their own profit. In earnest, they have reason to require a very favourable belief from their patients; and, indeed, it ought to be a very easy one, to swallow things so hard to be believed. Plato said very well, that physicians were the only men who might lie at pleasure, since our health depends upon the vanity and falsity of their promises.
commentaries: The author references Nicocles to support the idea that physicians benefit from both success and failure, and then cites Plato's view that physicians are permitted to lie due to their influence over health.

raw.title: Life of Thales
raw.author: Diogenes Laertius
contexts:
Thales, once inveighing in discourse against the pains and care men put themselves to to become rich, was answered by one in the company, that he did like the fox, who found fault with what he could not obtain. Whereupon, he had a mind, for the jest’s sake, to show them to the contrary; and having, for this occasion, made a muster of all his wits, wholly to employ them in the service of profit and gain, he set a traffic on foot, which in one year brought him in so great riches, that the most experienced in that trade could hardly in their whole lives, with all their industry, have raked so much together.—[Diogenes Laertius, Life of Thales, i.
26; Cicero, De Divin., i.
49.
]
commentaries: The author recounts the story of Thales's profitable venture, citing Diogenes Laertius's 'Life of Thales' as a source.

“Deprendas animi tormenta latentis in aegro Corpore; deprendas et gaudia; sumit utrumque Inde habitum facies.” [“You may discern the torments of mind lurking in a sick body; you may discern its joys: either expression the face assumes from the mind.”—Juvenal, ix. 18]
"Vascones, ut fama est, alimentis talibus usi Produxere animas." ["'Tis said the Gascons with such meats appeased their hunger." —Juvenal, Sat., xv. 93.]

"Rari quippe boni: numero vix sunt totidem quot Thebarum portae, vel divitis ostia Nili," ["Good men forsooth are scarce: there are hardly as many as there are gates of Thebes or mouths of the rich Nile." —Juvenal, Sat., xiii. 26.]

“Ad haec se Romanus Graiusque, et Barbaras induperator Erexit; caucus discriminis atque laboris Inde habuit: tanto major famae sitis est, quam Virtutis.” [“For these the Roman, the Greek, and the Barbarian commander hath aroused himself; he has incurred thence causes of danger and toil: so much greater is the thirst for fame than for virtue.” —Juvenal, x. 137.]

“Nec minimo sane discrimine refert, Quo gestu lepores, et quo gallina secetur;” [“Nor with less discrimination observes how we should carve a hare, and how a hen.” or, (“Nor with the least discrimination relates how we should carve hares, and how cut up a hen.)” —Juvenal, Sat., v. 123.]
"Occultum quatiens animo tortore flagellum." ["The torturer of the soul brandishing a sharp scourge within." —Juvenal, iii. 195.]

"Prima est haec ultio, quod se Judice nemo nocens absohitur." ["Tis the first punishment of sin that no man absolves himself." or: "This is the highest revenge, that by its judgment no offender is absolved."—Juvenal, xiii. 2.]

"Crocodilon adorat Pars haec; illa pavet saturam serpentibus ibin: Effigies sacri hic nitet aurea cercopitheci; Hic piscem flumints, illic Oppida tota canem venerantur." ["This place adores the crocodile; another dreads the ibis, feeder on serpents; here shines the golden image of the sacred ape; here men venerate the fish of the river; there whole towns worship a dog."—Juvenal, xv. 2.]
"Tanti mihi non sit opaci Omnis arena Tagi, quodque in mare volvitur aurum." ["I would not buy rich Tagus sands so dear, nor all the gold that lies in the sea."—Juvenal, Sat., iii. 54.]

"Nunc, si depositum non inficiatur amicus, Si reddat veterem cum tota aerugine follem, Prodigiosa fides, et Tuscis digna libellis, Quaeque coronata lustrari debeat agna:" ["Now, if a friend does not deny his trust, but restores the old purse with all its rust; 'tis a prodigious faith, worthy to be enrolled in amongst the Tuscan annals, and a crowned lamb should be sacrificed to such exemplary integrity."—Juvenal, Sat., xiii. 611.]
"Numquam adeo foedis, adeoque pudendis Utimur exemplis, ut non pejora supersint." ["The examples we use are not so shameful and foul but that worse remain behind."—Juvenal, viii. 183.]
“Et patimur longae pacis mala; saevior armis Luxuria incumbit.” [“And we suffer the ills of a long peace; luxury is more pernicious than war.”—Juvenal, vi. 291.]
"Converso pollice vulgi, Quemlibet occidunt populariter." ["The populace, with inverted thumbs, kill all that come before them."—Juvenal, iii. 36]
"Imponit finem sapiens et rebus honestis." ["The wise man limits even honest things."—Juvenal, vi. 444]

"Uberibus semper lacrymis, semperque paratis, In statione subatque expectantibus illam, Quo jubeat manare modo." ["A woman has ever a fountain of tears ready to gush up whenever she requires to make use of them."—Juvenal, vi. 272.]
“Et versus digitos habet:” [“Verse has fingers.”—Altered from Juvenal, iv. 196.]

“Fatum est in partibus illis Quas sinus abscondit; nam, si tibi sidera cessent, Nil faciet longi mensura incognita nervi;” [“There is a fatality about the hidden parts: let nature have endowed you however liberally, ‘tis of no use, if your good star fails you in the nick of time.”—Juvenal, ix. 32.]
“Adhuc ardens rigidae tentigine vulvae Et lassata viris, nondum satiata, recessit:” [“Ardent still, she retired, fatigued, but not satisfied.” —Juvenal, vi. 128.]

“Pone seram; cohibe: sed quis custodiet ipsos Custodes? cauta est, et ab illis incipit uxor.” [“Put on a lock; shut them up under a guard; but who shall guard the guard? she knows what she is about, and begins with them.” —Juvenal, vi. 346.]

"Dum nova canities, dum prima et recta senectus, Dum superest lachesi quod torqueat, et pedibus me Porto meis, nullo dextram subeunte bacillo," ["Whilst the white hair is new, whilst old age is still straight shouldered, whilst there still remains something for Lachesis to spin, whilst I walk on my own legs, and need no staff to lean upon." —Juvenal, iii. 26.]

["Let him go out, he said, if he has any sense of shame, and rise from the equestrian cushion, whose estate does not satisfy the law." —Juvenal, iii. 153. The Equites were required to possess a fortune of 400 sestertia, and they sat on the first fourteen rows behind the orchestra.]

"Pejoraque saecula ferri Temporibus, quorum sceleri non invenit ipsa Nomen, et a nullo posuit natura metallo;" ["And, worse than the iron ages, for whose crimes there is no similitude in any of Nature's metals."—Juvenal, xiii. 28.]
"Curentur dubii medicis majoribus aegri." ["Desperate maladies require the best doctors." —Juvenal, xiii. 124.]

"Ad primum lapidem vectari quum placet, hora Sumitur ex libro; si prurit frictus ocelli Angulus, inspecta genesi, collyria quaerit;" ["When he is pleased to have himself carried to the first milestone, the hour is chosen from the almanac; if he but rub the corner of his eye, his horoscope having been examined, he seeks the aid of salves."—Juvenal, vi. 576.]

contexts: a scholar shall be taught to know— “Quid fas optare: quid asper Utile nummus habet: patrix carisque propinquis Quantum elargiri deceat: quern te Deus esse Jussit, et humana qua parte locatus es in re; Quid sumus, et quidnam victuri gignimur.” [“Learn what it is right to wish; what is the true use of coined money; how much it becomes us to give in liberality to our country and our dear relations; whom and what the Deity commanded thee to be; and in what part of the human system thou art placed; what we are ant to what purpose engendered.”—Persius, iii. 69]

"Rupi jam vincula, dicas Nam luctata canis nodum arripit; attamen illi, Quum fugit, a collo trahitur pars longa catenae." ["You say, perhaps, you have broken your chains: the dog who after long efforts has broken his chain, still in his flight drags a heavy portion of it after him."—Persius, Sat., v. 158.]
"Usque adeone Scire tuum, nihil est, nisi to scire hoc, sciat alter?" ["Is all that thy learning nothing, unless another knows that thou knowest?"—Persius, Sat., i. 23.]

"Carpamus dulcia; nostrum est, Quod vivis; cinis, et manes, et fabula fies." ["Let us pluck life’s sweets, 'tis for them we live: by and by we shall be ashes, a ghost, a mere subject of talk." —Persius, Sat., v. 151.]
"Tun', vetule, auriculis alienis colligis escas?" ["Dost thou, then, old man, collect food for others’ ears?" —Persius, Sat., i. 22.]
"Puellae Hunc rapiant; quidquid calcaverit hic, rosa fiat," ["Let girls carry him off; wherever he steps let there spring up a rose!"—Persius, Sat., ii. 38.]
"Quae, nisi seductis, nequeas committere divis" [“Which you can only impart to the gods, when you have gained them over.”—Persius, ii. 4.]

"Hoc igitur, quo to Jovis aurem impellere tentas, Dic agedum Staio: 'proh Jupiter! O bone, clamet, Jupiter!' At sese non clamet Jupiter ipse." [“This therefore, with which you seek to draw the ear of Jupiter, say to Staius. ‘O Jupiter! O good Jupiter!’ let him cry. Think you Jupiter himself would not cry out upon it?”—Persius, ii. 21.]

"Haud cuivis promptum est, murmurque, humilesque susurros Tollere de templis, et aperto vivere voto" [“‘Tis not convenient for every one to bring the prayers he mutters out of the temple, and to give his wishes to the public ear. —“Persius, ii. 6.]

"Laudari metuam, neque enim mihi cornea fibra est Sed recti finemque extremumque esse recuso Euge tuum, et belle." ["I should fear to be praised, for my heart is not made of horn; but I deny that 'excellent—admirably done,' are the terms and final aim of virtue."—Persius, i. 47.]

"Non quicquid turbida Roma Elevet, accedas; examenque improbum in illa Castiges trutina: nec to quaesiveris extra." ["Do not, if turbulent Rome disparage anything, accede; nor correct a false balance by that scale; nor seek anything beyond thyself." —Persius, Sat., i. 5.]
"Nemo in sese tentat descendere;" ["No one thinks of descending into himself." —Persius, iv. 23.]

"Non equidem hoc studeo, bullatis ut mihi nugis, Pagina turgescat...... Secreti loquimur:" ["I study not to make my pages swell with empty trifles; you and I are talking in private."—Persius, Sat., v. 19.]
"Excutienda damus praecordia." ["We give our hearts to be examined."—Persius, V.
"Dare pondus idonea fumo." ["Able to give weight to smoke."—Persius, v. 20.]

raw.author: Terence
contexts: "Honesta oratio est;" ["Fine words truly."—Ter. And., i. I, 114.]
and then Terence

“Vah! quemquamne hominem in animum instituere, aut Parare, quod sit carius, quam ipse est sibi?” [“Ah! can any man conceive in his mind or realise what is dearer than he is to himself?”—Terence, Adelph., i. I, 13.]
for that the work was theirs, its beauty and excellence sufficiently declare; Terence himself confesses as much, and I should take it ill from any one that would dispossess me of that belief.

"Haec perinde sunt, ut ilius animus; qui ea possidet Qui uti scit, ei bona; illi, qui non uritur recte, mala." ["Things are, as is the mind of their possessor; who knows how to use them, to him they are good; to him who abuses them, ill." —Terence, Heart., i. 3, 21.]

“Hoc salsum est, hoc adustum est, hoc lautum est, parum: Illud recte: iterum sic memento: sedulo Moneo, qux possum, pro mea sapientia. Postremo, tanquam in speculum, in patinas, Demea, Inspicere jubeo, et moneo, quid facto usus sit.” [“This is too salt, that’s burnt, that’s not washed enough; that’s well; remember to do so another time. Thus do I ever advise them to have things done properly, according to my capacity; and lastly, Demea, I command my cooks to look into every dish as if it were a mirror, and tell them what they should do.” —Terence, Adelph., iii. 3, 71.]
“Humani a se nihil alienum putet.” [“Let him not think himself exempt from that which is incidental to men in general.”—Terence, Heauton, i. 1, 25.]

"Et errat longe mea quidem sententia Qui imperium credat esse gravius, aut stabilius, Vi quod fit, quam illud, quod amicitia adjungitur." ["He wanders far from the truth, in my opinion, who thinks that government more absolute and durable which is acquired by force than that which is attached to friendship."—Terence, Adelph., i. I, 40.]
"Ille solos nescit omnia." ["He alone is ignorant of all that is passing." —Terence, Adelph., iv. 2, 9.]

As for good Terence, the refined elegance and grace of the Latin tongue, I find him admirable in his vivid representation of our manners and the movements of the soul; our actions throw me at every turn upon him; and I cannot read him so often that I do not still discover some new grace and beauty.
“Tibi quod superest, mihi quod desit, dolet.” [“Your superfluities trouble you, and what I want troubles me.—“Terence, Phoym., i. 3, 9.]
"Spem pretio non emo." ["I will not purchase hope with ready money," (or), "I do not purchase hope at a price." —Terence, Adelphi, ii. 3, 11.]
"Plenus rimarum sum, hac atque iliac perfluo." ["I’m full of chinks, and leak out every way." —Ter., Eunuchus, ii. 2, 23.]
"Dum in dubio est animus, paulo momento huc atque Illuc impellitur." ["While the mind is in doubt, in a short time it is impelled this way and that."—Terence, Andr., i. 6, 32.]
"Nae iste magno conatu magnas nugas dixerit." ["Truly he, with a great effort will shortly say a mighty trifle." —-Terence, Heaut., act iii., s. 4.]

"Ubi velis, nolunt; ubi nolis, volunt ultro; Concessa pudet ire via." ["Where thou wilt, they won't; where thou wilt not, they spontaneously agree; they are ashamed to go in the permitted path." —Terence, Eunuchus, act iv., sc. 8, v 43]

"Nostri nosmet paenitet." ["We are ashamed of ourselves."—Terence, Phoymio, i.
3, 20.]

"Haec si tu postules Ratione certa facere, nihilo plus agas, Quam si des operam, ut cum ratione insanias:" ["If you seek to make these things certain by reason, you will do no more than if you should seek to be mad in your senses." —Terence, Eun., act i., sc. i, v. 16.]
"Quod vos jus cogit, vix voluntate impetrent:" ["That which the laws compel us to do, we scarcely do with a will." —Terence, Adelph., iii. 3, 44.]

"Uxor, si cesses, aut to amare cogitat, Aut tete amari, aut potare, aut animo obsequi; Et tibi bene esse soli, cum sibi sit male;" ["Your wife, if you loiter, thinks that you love or are beloved; or that you are drinking or following your inclination; and that it is well for you when it is ill for her (all the pleasure is yours and hers all the care)." —Terence, Adelph., act i., sc. I, v. 7.]

goodreads_match.title: Hippias Major
goodreads_match.description:
In the Hippias Major, Socrates and Hippias set out to find a definition for "beauty", but are destined to fail due to their inability to formulate an answer which encompasses the entire concept. The actual Greek term that is used in the dialogue is kalon, which as an adjective often means fine or noble as well as beautiful. For this reason, translators such as Paul Woodruff typically translate the term (to kalon--the abstract noun of the adjective) as "the Fine" (things) instead of "Beauty."

He became famous in rhetoric, philosophy, money-making, and imperial service. After some disgrace during Claudius' reign he became tutor and then, in 54 CE, advising minister to Nero, some of whose worst misdeeds he did not prevent.
